question.text: Some people think the news has no connection to people's lives, so then it is a waste of time to read the news in the newspaper and watch television news programs. To what extent do you agree or disagree?

questionType.explanation: You must state how much you agree or disagree with the statement that news is irrelevant and a waste of time.
requirements: State your position clearly (strongly agree/disagree or partially agree)
Give specific examples related to news and daily life
Address the opposing view if taking a balanced position

keyWords.importance: This is the claim you must agree or disagree with

keyWords.definition: Daily experiences and concerns of ordinary citizens
keyWords.importance: Consider how news impacts daily life
You must argue whether news consumption is valuable or not

keyWords.definition: How much or to what degree
keyWords.importance: You can fully agree, fully disagree, or partially agree

essayStructure.introduction: 2-3 sentences: Paraphrase question + state your position clearly
essayStructure.body1: 4-5 sentences: Main reason supporting your position with examples
essayStructure.body2: 4-5 sentences: Additional reason or opposing view (if balanced)
essayStructure.conclusion: 2 sentences: Summarize position and provide final thought

commonMistakes: Only discussing news types without connecting to relevance
Forgetting to explain HOW news connects to people's lives
Not addressing the 'waste of time' part of the question

structure.introduction: I strongly disagree with the view that [news is irrelevant]. In my opinion, [state why news is important].
structure.body1: [Main reason news is relevant - Topic sentence]. This is because [Explanation]. For instance, [Specific example]. As a result, [Consequence].
structure.body2: Furthermore, [Additional reason]. [Explanation of second benefit]. For example, [Supporting example]. Therefore, [Conclusion about importance].
structure.conclusion: In conclusion, [restate disagreement]. [Final thought on why news matters for society].

example.introduction: I strongly disagree with the view that news has no connection to people's lives. In my opinion, staying informed through news media is essential for responsible citizenship and informed decision-making.
example.body1: Firstly, news directly impacts people's daily lives through policy and economic information. Citizens need to understand how government decisions affect their finances, healthcare, and employment opportunities. For instance, news about tax changes or unemployment benefits enables families to plan their budgets accordingly. As a result, informed citizens can make better financial and personal decisions.
example.body2: Furthermore, news consumption empowers democratic participation. Knowledge of current affairs enables voters to evaluate candidates and hold elected officials accountable. For example, during elections, voters rely on news coverage to understand policy positions and candidate qualifications. Therefore, an informed electorate is crucial for healthy democracy.
example.conclusion: In conclusion, I firmly believe that news remains highly relevant to people's lives. Rather than being a waste of time, consuming news is an investment in informed citizenship and personal empowerment.

structure.introduction: While I acknowledge that [some news lacks relevance], I believe that [quality news remains important]. This essay will discuss [both perspectives].
structure.body1: On the one hand, [concede point about irrelevant news]. [Explanation]. For example, [Example of low-value news]. [Why this supports the criticism].
structure.body2: On the other hand, [argue for news importance]. [Main reason]. For instance, [Example of valuable news]. [Impact on citizens]. Moreover, [Additional benefit of staying informed].
structure.conclusion: To summarize, while [acknowledge concern], [state position that valuable news outweighs trivial content].

structure.introduction: I completely disagree that [news is a waste of time]. From my perspective, [news plays a vital role].
structure.body1: [Primary argument for news relevance]. [Reason 1 with explanation]. [Reason 2 with explanation]. For example, [Comprehensive example covering both reasons].
structure.body2: Although some argue that [counter-argument], this overlooks [your rebuttal]. [Explanation of why news remains valuable despite concerns]. [Example supporting your view].
structure.conclusion: In conclusion, despite [acknowledge concern], [firmly restate position that news is essential].

steps.title: Build Paragraphs
steps.completionCriteria: Complete all 4 paragraphs (10+ words per blank)

content.instructions: Fill in each blank to build your essay paragraph by paragraph. Aim for 10-15 words per blank. Click 'Show Hint' if you need help.

paragraphs.name: Introduction
paragraphs.template: I strongly disagree with the view that _____ [state the claim about news being irrelevant]. In my opinion, _____ [clearly state YOUR position on why news matters].

blanks.label: State the claim about news
blanks.hint: Paraphrase 'news has no connection to people's lives and is a waste of time'
blanks.placeholder: e.g., news media has no relevance to ordinary citizens and consuming it serves no practical purpose

blanks.label: Your position on news importance
blanks.hint: State clearly why news IS important. Use strong language showing disagreement.
blanks.placeholder: e.g., staying informed through news is essential for democratic participation and making informed personal decisions

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 1
paragraphs.template: Firstly, _____ [topic sentence about why news is relevant]. This is because _____ [explain the reason/mechanism]. For instance, _____ [give a specific example]. As a result, _____ [state the consequence or benefit].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - news relevance
blanks.hint: Main reason why news IS relevant to people's lives
blanks.placeholder: e.g., news provides essential information that directly affects people's financial and personal decisions

blanks.label: Explain the reason
blanks.hint: WHY or HOW does news provide this benefit? Explain the mechanism.
blanks.placeholder: e.g., government policies, economic changes, and health information reported in news directly impact household budgets and daily planning

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Give a concrete example - real situation showing news relevance
blanks.placeholder: e.g., during the COVID-19 pandemic, news updates about restrictions and health measures were crucial for protecting families and understanding policy changes

blanks.label: Consequence/benefit
blanks.hint: What is the final outcome? How does this show news is NOT a waste of time?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., citizens who stay informed can make better decisions that protect their interests and improve their quality of life

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 2
paragraphs.template: Moreover, _____ [topic sentence about additional benefit of news]. _____ [explain why this matters]. For example, _____ [specific example]. Therefore, _____ [conclusion about this perspective].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - additional benefit
blanks.hint: Second main reason why news matters. Could be about democracy, civic engagement, etc.
blanks.placeholder: e.g., news consumption empowers democratic participation and enables citizens to hold leaders accountable

blanks.label: Explain why this matters
blanks.hint: Explain the mechanism or reasoning behind this second benefit
blanks.placeholder: e.g., understanding candidates' policies and government actions requires following news coverage, which allows voters to make informed electoral choices and engage in meaningful civic discourse

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Concrete example showing how news enables civic participation
blanks.placeholder: e.g., voters who follow news about candidates' positions and track records are better equipped to evaluate their options during elections

blanks.label: Conclusion about this view
blanks.hint: Wrap up this perspective - emphasize why this makes news valuable, not a waste
blanks.placeholder: e.g., an informed electorate is fundamental to healthy democracy, making news consumption a civic responsibility rather than wasted time

paragraphs.name: Conclusion
paragraphs.template: In conclusion, _____ [restate your disagreement with the claim]. _____ [final thought on why news matters for individuals and society].

blanks.label: Restate disagreement
blanks.hint: Clearly restate that you disagree news is irrelevant/waste of time
blanks.placeholder: e.g., I firmly maintain that news has significant relevance to people's lives and is far from being a waste of time

blanks.label: Final thought on news importance
blanks.hint: End with a strong statement about why news matters - think bigger picture
blanks.placeholder: e.g., staying informed through quality news sources empowers citizens to make better decisions and participate effectively in democratic society, making it an investment rather than a waste

content.instructions: Now combine your paragraphs into a complete essay. You can copy from Step 5 and edit, or write fresh. Aim for 250-280 words total.

introduction.purpose: Paraphrase question + state your position clearly (agree/disagree)

body1.purpose: Discuss first main reason with explanation and example

body2.purpose: Discuss second reason or address counter-argument

checklist: Body paragraph 1 explains why news IS relevant with example
Body paragraph 2 provides additional reason or addresses opposition
Conclusion restates position and provides final insight
Variety of sentence structures (simple, compound, complex)
Linking words used to connect ideas

modelEssay.text:
Some people contend that news media lacks relevance to ordinary citizens' lives and therefore represents a waste of time. I strongly disagree with this view, as staying informed through news is essential for both personal decision-making and democratic participation.

Firstly, news provides crucial information that directly impacts people's daily lives and financial well-being. Government policies, economic developments, and health advisories reported through news outlets affect household budgets, employment prospects, and family planning decisions. For instance, during the COVID-19 pandemic, people relied heavily on news updates to understand lockdown measures, health guidelines, and financial support programs. Similarly, news about tax policy changes or interest rate adjustments enables citizens to make informed decisions about major purchases, investments, and savings strategies. Without access to this information, individuals would struggle to navigate the complex systems that govern their lives.

Moreover, news consumption empowers civic engagement and strengthens democratic processes. An informed citizenry is fundamental to healthy democracy, as voters need knowledge of current affairs to evaluate candidates and hold elected officials accountable. For example, understanding politicians' voting records, policy positions, and responses to community concerns requires following news coverage throughout election cycles. Furthermore, awareness of social issues through news reporting enables citizens to participate meaningfully in public discourse and advocate for positive change in their communities.

In conclusion, I firmly maintain that news has profound relevance to people's lives rather than being a waste of time. Far from being unnecessary, consuming quality news represents an investment in informed citizenship and personal empowerment that benefits both individuals and society.
